p: Higher concentrations of PM 2.5 from anthropogenic sources can result from changes in precursor emissions, in meteorology and in the physical and chemical behaviour of particles in the atmosphere [ 11•]. Besides anthropogenic emissions, future climate will change the emissions of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) due to higher temperatures and changed plant metabolism; this can alter secondary organic aerosols (SOAs) resulting in changes in secondary particle levels [ 12]. More and larger wildfires associated with climate change could significantly reduce air quality by the end of the century [ 13]. Other natural sources include dust storms and dust particle transport; climate change could increase their frequency [ 11•]. For example, Jacob and Winner [ 14] concluded that due to climate change (mainly due to weaker global circulation and a decreasing frequency of mid-latitude cyclones), annual mean PM 2.5 concentrations will change by ± 1 μg/m 3 in the USA and Europe.
